w.t: to swell or rise (as beans, etc.)
to rip grass from house, etc.
to praise the wealth of another
to begin to get wrinkled (with age)
to empty out all of a liquid
to stretch out (v.t.) (as skin for drum)
to tell chief that someone sends in "bgakeye"
and (used for connecting clauses, not words in a series)
to clean up field at, for
to take away grass that's been hoed out
ghost (thing which resembles person but has supernatural powers)
to be taken sick suddenly (supposedly from python looking at one)
to mix things up and pack them down together
to desire to harm another without reason
to squeeze out juice to last drop
to be severe toward, at, for
to put food in sun to dry
suffix used to form the feminine (e.g. inkokokazi - hen)
to cut (meat, finger, cloth, paper, etc.)
jealously (esp. between wives of same husband)
speaking evil of another with whom you share work
to feel the way before one with foot or spear
to look around on all sides
to be jealous of each other
small pot girls put butter in
to shake down to separate from dirt (e.g. millet)
to see that someone wishes to see you alone
to cut up in small pieces
to cut wool of sheep, tail of animal
to cut off top of tree
to look carefully to see if anyone is there
to persist patiently, in or at
to tie clothes at waist with
to die or break suddenly or unexpectedly
to attempt something beyond one's strength
to smart in mouth to slander
to rejoice at arrival of someone
to give warm welcome (one does not say it of himself)
bush with thorns and edible berries
to spend all night without sleeping
(from guca) good morning (greeting used almost any time of day if first meeting)
to lay someone on his side
to take one's arms (baby), to hug
to point out truth to those arguing
to not say directly ("go around Robin Hood's barn")
to step aside to make light
to step aside to let ligh in
any four-sided figure (originally, a place fixed for pole -vaulting)
evil spirit worshipped by Barundi - similar to Satan
place where steps are cut in hillside
a calamity (such as a bad disease or plague)
to make a little hole in ground for planting a tree or plant
to dig up sweet potato with fingers
to strip one of his clothing
to roll up (v.i.), e.g. a skin that's been wet
to persist more strongly than before
to be paid for for marriage
daughter of my (your, his) sister, if I'm a girl
daughter of my (your, his) brother, if I'm a boy
scar left by person scratching or biting another
to strip leaves from tree or stick
to strip off leaves for, because of
leaves or bark stripped from tree
to touch a person to attract his attention
framework of branches on which smaller ones are interlaced in building a house
to knock (originally, to strike earth to make ants come out)
to strike one against the other (as knees, etc., in fear or cold)
to clean up onet's plate completely
to be born of a certain family
to stop a thing because someone has repeatedly warned and advised you
to succeed in persuading someone to leave his evil ways
to pick squash or corn from stalk
to go together to see something (of many people)
to help another to overcome an enemy
gushira igikonyo - to work with zeal
it's enough (salt, medicine, etc.) in something else
to eat what's left on peeling of roasted banana, etc.
to cause to fall in abundance
to fall down (as branches blown down) continually, in abundance
gukorana mu minwe na ... to shake hands with
charm or horn used by witch doctor
charm or horn used by witch doctor
to cause to fall down from above
stoop-shouldered-ness (as result of illness or hunger) (term of scorn)
to eat two kinds of food together
to have to return home because of bad news
thunder (actually, the imaginary animal that makes the thunder)
to shave off fibers for thread
to drag along quickly (as wind or river) (v.t.)
to beat at, for because of
to rise (as bread, or anything containing leaven)
very heavy rain (sweeps away crops on hillsides)
to curve finger (as in scraping food from dish)
pile of mixed grain and chaff
one who keeps the crowd back
to cause to love each other
to come together (as crowd of people)
group of attendants or helpers to elders
to follow one after the other
to have younger brothers or sisters
to pull grass away from base of plant
to be about to give birth
to take away by means of
to drag along a very heavy thing
to be willing to be admonished
ground corn that has first been roasted
to put handle on at, for
to cause to put handle on
to be worthy of each other
